transcript:
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
I'm Brad Roth, Chief Investment Officer of Thor Financial Technologies, and portfolio manager
of THLV, the Thor Low Volatility ETF.
Behind the Ticker, uncovers the inner workings of the ETF industry.
We will interview portfolio managers and ETF service providers to dive deep into their
work lives and their businesses.
We will learn the inner workings of their strategies and what drives them as they continue
to grow their company.
Many of these individuals are entrepreneurs, and will have unique and compelling insights
to share as much goes on behind the Ticker.
Please note, nothing in this show is investment advice, and it is meant solely for
educational and entertainment purposes only.
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
Today we have Ryan Pennell, he is the founder of Kaiju Advisors.
He runs a handful of private funds and also his ETF dip, DIP.
The Ticker explains at a very high level to strategy, but there is much, much more
behind the hood as Ryan is a true AI specialist.
This is a 100% totally AI-wrong strategy.
We get into AI and what it means and how it operates to make investments decisions specifically
in his strategies.
I could have talked to Ryan for probably three or four hours.
It is very educational, it is also very insightful.
He does a wonderful job articulating what their strategy is and what they are trying to accomplish
and how they have built their systems.
So I really hope you enjoy this episode with Ryan Pennell.
Ryan, welcome to the show.
Thank you very much, Brad.
Nice to be here.
So before we get started, please explain everybody, your background and how you eventually
decided to start Kaiju Advisors.
That is a loaded question and there is a secure answer to it.
So I will try not to just go off on tangent after tangent.
My background, I guess the most recent apical background,
I spent time in applied cryptography and theoretical physics.
I became an equity trader and then a portfolio manager for a large hedge fund and then I started
my own hedge fund and then funds.
Always quantitative in terms of process and about half a decade ago, I started using artificial
intelligence, which we had used in a limited capacity while I was doing cryptography work in
support of random number generation protocols.
We started applying that to investment management on the private fund side and that's been
very successful for us.
A couple of years ago we were wondering why we were not seeing this on the public fund side very much.
AI was really not being used to its full capacity.
There were a couple of funds that were using it as a filtering and calling mechanism,
but really not for end-point decision-making.
We started to investigate the possibility of taking one or two of our strategies that had
been successful for us on the private fund side and converting them into an ETF.
There was one in particular that fit the bill for our partners, for the market makers.
We felt responsibly for the market at the time and that was a load of high mean reversion
strategy, so that's a geeky way of saying a dip buying strategy, it's looking for
artificially oversold stocks and we turned that into an ETF last December, launched it on the
New York Stock Exchange, ticker is dip, DIP and that came down to the floor.
One of only six ETFs on the New York Stock Exchange floor a couple of months ago,
Citadel helped us bring it down, so that was a big day for us.
And it's been great so far. It's nice to watch something that you've spent a long time building
successfully operate. I'm sure as you know, like on the private fund side,
there's a lot of secret sauce there and a lot of undisclosed performance outside depending on your offering
memorandum, depending on what your allowed to share and not share.
So it's nice to have an ETF that's publicly accessible, performance is publicly viewable.
I think we're somewhere around 12% plus 12% in the last 90 days, so that's been good for us.
And we're just looking forward to trying to make these type of AI curated and directed
training systems more accessible. Because today, I mean, what you've really seen these in
high-end hedge funds, which your average investor is never going to get access to. So this is a
way to sort of bring it to a broader investment base and hopefully do some good with it.
Yeah, so it's interesting. You being the sixth fund of the floor, we were actually the fifth.
So I was actually looking at your, given the nature of what I, you guys do, I was looking at your
premium discounts and it looks like it's really done wonders for you guys in terms of keeping adherence
to NAV pretty pretty strong. And that's the experience we've got and it seems like you've got the same
experience as well. Yeah, that's for sure. I mean, nothing against being up on ARCA,
you know, that that was a good place for us to start and the nice you guys were super assistive
and getting us up there. We were really grateful to GTS, who is our LMM when we launched,
helping us with that. But with something that's, you know, has a, has a lower AUM and is
thankfully trading daily. But, you know, when you're just getting started, there's not a ton of
volume there. And when you get spreads that are a 10, 12 cents and retail traders coming in with
market orders, you know, they can get some disadvantages fills. And, you know, our concern was that they
may not understand why they were getting disadvantages fills. You know, they get filled up at the
offer, or especially five minutes from open. It's a big blowout in spread. They get, you know,
an erroneous match, you know, and they're like, you know, your ETF is 26 bucks and they get
filled at 32.05 and you're like, oh my God, this poor guy, like, can we, can we find out who it was?
Can we do anything? And, and, and, and really coming down to the floor with Citadel's
tighten that up to like two, three cents, you know, for the trading day. So we can be confident that
the investor is going to get, you know, a more appropriate fill relative to NAV. Yeah, and that's what
they were trying to accomplish and they did a good job at accomplishing that. We had a similar
experience with an advisor putting market orders in and closing auction over the counter. So where
will do you think they were going to get filled at? And, you know, you feel bad for them and then
you feel bad for, you know, your actual investors who are trying to get a clean clothes. But I
digress, it's good that you're down there. I think we're going to see a lot more of that. But I was
like to ask to before we get too deep into it. What other hobbies you have when you're not working?
What are some of the things you like to do before you and I run the call you mentioned? This was an
old ski room of yours. Do you a ski or a snowboarder? I do snowboard. Yes, I'm a terrible skier.
I was, I, I started as a skateboarder and then a surfer. So snowboarding for me was the, the
logical progression. Still, you know, this is the right now. I'm on the west coast of Canada
in Whistler. Usually here for the summer and at Christmas, normally I'm based out of Geneva.
And, you know, here in Whistler, it's maybe a 60, 40 skier snowboarder split in the Alps. It's more like
90, 10. So I still have like this pariah moments or you end up on a run that definitely was not
designed for a snowboarder. But yeah, so I do that in the winter. I'm a big ocean conservationist
and heavily involved in, in philanthropic initiatives to do with ocean conservancy. So I'm a free
diver, master scuba diver, sailor. Love, I'm happiest, you know, on in or under the water.
Yeah. So that's, that's kind of my thing. And I added, I added helicopter piloting last year, but
I'm not very good at that. So, you know, maybe just practice in that on simulator until you
get a little better at it, you know. Yeah, I like to say, you know, like if it's zombie apocalypse,
like I'm your guy, I can definitely get us out of there roughly. But if you, if you want to,
if you want to grab the family and go for a little cruise over the Alps, there are much better
choices. Helicopter pilots than me. That's great. So let's talk about the firm before we kind of
get into process and product. Do you guys offer any other services to clients other than just the
ETF? Is there any other advisory services you guys work on or things that you do? On the RIA side
know, as we just, we just create and then launch AI curated and directed ETFs. And we have several
more in the pipe. Dip was just our most accessible test. And on the private fund side,
we do manage four funds through a KIDU capital management. KIDU ETF advisors is the, is the SEC
registered RIA that deals with the ETFs. And KIDU capital management is our, is our BBI based approved
manager, which deals with private funds. So we do have private funds. They're all fully subscribed
at this time. We don't really have much of a plan to add an additional fund. We have a new one coming
out, but it started its life fully subscribed. So we'll see what happens with that. We talked
previously about maybe offering some consultative services out to other managers interested in
getting into artificial intelligence. But to be perfectly honest, I really don't, I don't see how
that would work, given our, our capacity right now. We're just, we're, we're at or above capacity
all the time. And there's, there's, there's private fund initiatives in the pipe. There's ETFs in the
pipe. And that, that sort of takes up all our time. I wish, I wish I could say that there were
other opportunities, but currently none available. Well, that's, I mean, that's, there, there
are a lot of opportunities already there and, and in the pipe. And so while we, what we talk about
AI, and you're right, you know, there aren't a whole lot of offerings in the space. I know we're
going to see, you know, like we saw with with crypto and Bitcoin, everybody trying to come out with
an AI product, but you've been in it for a very long time. Before we kind of get in the investment
management side of AI, because I am interested in hearing some of your opinions there, you and I
talked to a lot of advisors and just wanted to get kind of your opinion on where you think
disruptions going to, how it's going to affect their business, right? In the advice and
recommendation business, or if at all, I think it's important to have a person there, but it's hard
to ignore what's coming down in terms of AI's capabilities and how it might affect that community
rather than just ours. Yeah, I mean, I don't think it represents quite the same level of doom
and gloom that others have posited recently. Like you said, you know, there needs, I think broadly
there needs to be a person there, right? Like people don't articulate their risk parameters,
their investment objectives, very well, to a machine. Like I mean, if it was going to be automated,
it would start with some sort of intensive AI calibrated questionnaire that you would fill out, right?
But, you know, there needs to be some level of challenge. I think as any RIA would tell you or any
FA would tell you, like in meeting with a client and understanding what their objectives are,
what they say, what they need, what they can tolerate, what they express, they can tolerate,
what they actually can, are often very different things. And that's a process that we're the
FA's experience really comes into playing. You know, you need to just because somebody says,
well, this is what I've gotten. I don't, I want high risk and high return and I don't care if I lose it all.
There needs to be a deeper dive into the impact of that decision, right? They might say they don't
care whether they lose it all. But, okay, in addition to this, what's your capital reserve,
what kind of debt are you carrying currently? Like you might, you might not even be in a position
to make this investment to start with, but nobody's told you that. So, AI can't do any of that.
It's terrible at context. It doesn't understand nuance. It's really great at smashing numbers.
So, I don't see it, I don't see it sort of taking that business away. I see it being a tool
that RIAs can use to get to answers more quickly. I think what you're going to see. Unfortunately,
I think Robo advisors are going to make a big comeback. And I think they'll be AI Robo advisors this time.
And I don't think that those are going to work out substantially better than they did the
first time around for the, for exactly the same reasons, right? You just, you can't just presume that
everyone is equal. And so, I'll just give you a basket of crap for you to buy and you go buy it.
But I do think that you'll see tools appear that are assistive tools for professional
managers so that an FA or an RIA sitting down with a client, understanding all of their needs,
what their assets are, risk tolerance, et cetera, will be able to use a tool to dial in a series
of potential packages that that investor might consider. It's well, we could go this route,
hear the pros and cons, we go this route, hear the pros and cons. So, that human is still there
to use the tool, just as I, you know, I think you'll see doctors using AI tools and a diagnostic
capacity, but the doctor will still be there to gather the information. And then that will result in
some increased output. I do think, yeah, if you have a crummy FA or RIA that's hanging in there,
but at the bottom end of the, of the, of the food chain, a bottom of the food chain there,
I think that AI portfolio generating systems might wipe those out, but I think that's a very,
very small cohort within the broader RIA space. Yeah, no, I think you and I share again,
very similar opinion there. I just, you know, we hear a lot from the advisor community and some of them
are worried. Some of them think they're going away and I just don't see it. But you and I can geek out
for probably hours about system building. I've, you know, been obsessed with how to build, you know,
mechanical portfolio strategies for a very long time. You have as well. So this, this is more to,
maybe more to be a fun question than a serious question. Do you remember like the first system you
built and, you know, what problems did you have to solve to get to where you are now to have,
you know, such successful running systems that you're able to kind of run, you know,
multi-private funds as well as a handful of ETFs. Yeah, I mean, I, I mean, I, I have those sort of
memories of different types of systems you've built for sure. I was part of the team that built the
first 16 core computer system, 96 gigs of RAM. We built our own daughter boards. We built our
own riser cards. It was running Windows 2000 server 64 bit and we had to build it in a filing cabinet
because there were no towers appropriately sized to take it. So it was in a filing cabinet and
drives and we're in subsequent drawers. But I think, you know, you were probably aiming more towards
the trading systems. And yeah, I mean, in 2019, we built a very, very early, less sophisticated
iteration of the system that we run now. And, you know, rigorously tested it throughout the year,
at the end of the year, you know, it was just crushing returns five straight months in a row.
And, you know, looking back in hindsight, I just, we all feel like idiots. Like, we were high
five in each other. That's it. We conquered the market. We solved it. It's done. I mean, the performance
was so outrageous that we weren't mentioning it to anyone because we just thought that they would,
you know, they would not have, we wouldn't believe it. So we were sitting there going, how are we
going to articulate this without looking like we're gambling or we're lying, like one of the two
things. You know, this was like serious conversations. And then the sixth month, this system
could not identify like deep sector rotation that occurred. And it drove like a bus full of my
money off a cliff. Like, in one month, it wiped out almost all of the profit of the previous five.
In one go, you know, and, you know, we took it offline. Obviously, immediately, some of the guys that
that worked on it, I like to say it was like they went off to their bedrooms and they wouldn't
come out for a week. Like, you can get a lot of slack and they weren't responding to emails.
Everyone was just sort of crushed by the fact that this thing that we thought was so sophisticated,
had this, you know, this capacity for fault. I always say today, I'm so grateful for that
because it wasn't catastrophic. We were way up and then this thing basically took us back to normal,
which is better than if it wiped us out. And it really paved the road to where we have got to now.
Like, we were in hindsight, the guardrails that we placed were way too far away from where they
should have been. We were really optimizing for profit, gross return. And that's almost black box,
right? When you're using a black box system, that's what you're going to get. You're going to
get a 7,000% 10-year return, but you'll have two or three periods while you'll be down 70 to 90%.
Right. You can't actually, unless you're just some, you know, billionaire that wants to mess
around and has money to throw at these things. Yeah, fine. You can run a system like that. But,
you know, if you're a responsible manager, you cannot put client money on a system like that.
No matter what the 10-year yield is, or your disclosures. And so, you know, we added layers of
risk mitigation. That was really the beginning of us building the arc, which is our AI risk containment
system. It's effectively an AI off-ramp, which handles all of that. And now, like, we don't come
anywhere close to that outcome. But I don't think I will ever forget that iteration of the system.
I mean, we gave it a name. It was TJ and TJ basically got drunk and drove off a cliff. So it's
funny now. It was not funny then. Yeah, I'm sure it's not funny. But it's an invaluable learning
experience, right? Like you need to have those because you go to market too soon with something
and it goes, it goes haywire at the wrong time. So that's a valuable lesson at the right time.
Yeah, humility as well, I think, you know. Oh, yeah. Absolutely. So just one more question on AI,
then I want to talk about dip extensively. I've read that you guys apply, you know, machine learning
to your AI systems. And I know you have guardrails in place. You just kind of iterated that. But
at what point do you think as the machine learns, does do the investment system decisions start to
come a little bit like unrecognizable or it doesn't sometimes make sense to you or does that happen
now? Like sometimes it might buy something and you say, man, that doesn't make sense.
Or it wasn't kind of the original design. Do you foresee that happening or do you have like
really strict guardrails in place to keep it really focused on certain defined opportunities?
Yes, it's somewhere in between the two. So, you know, true black box systems, you know,
their investment decisions cannot be explained because they don't follow a linear path like
we do in making investment decisions. You know, I always the way I try to explain it is, you know,
the way that AI makes decisions is this exactly the same as we do when we decide that we like a
piece of art or we find somebody attractive or we instantly like some music, right? So, you walk
into a room, it doesn't matter. You walk into a gallery and you see a piece of art on the wall.
You're like, instantly, you think, God, love that painting or you walk into a room and you see
somebody and you think, oh, man, they're attractive. If I stopped you in the moment and I said,
really, why? It would be hard for you to articulate that, right? You'd sort of back out of it and
you'd see, well, I don't, maybe, I don't know, the blues or the reds or if it's a person or I
like their eyes or you're like, you're not, you're brain-new at instantly. You didn't need to do
any further calculation. So, we do make decisions that way. We just don't make investing decisions
that way. We go through this linear process, quantitatively, okay, the criteria that I had, flagged,
were met. Now, I'm going to evaluate further, is your fundamentalist, your reading reports,
doing fundamental forward-looking analysis, et cetera, to come to the yes-no-by-sell-hold decision
that we make. So, AI doesn't do that. And black boxes, the most outside. So, you can't explain any of
that. With us, we have an investment ideology that we teach the machine. And it doesn't, on the
private one side, ETF side doesn't matter. It's always the same. There's a trading strategy,
which we start off with is developed by humans. We've used it before it's made us money. We teach
the machine. Then there's this refinement period that we go through, where within the guardrails that
we place. So, you cannot use this more than this in terms of capital. You cannot accept more than
this in terms of aggregate risk. If it's an equity, long-only equity strategy, you can't show it.
You can't access the options market. So, we put these controls in place. And we tell it what it's
trying to do with what we give it. Using these do that. And then we ask it for optimization output.
And it'll come back and say, okay, I can achieve that doing this. But I can achieve it better if I
slightly alter it in this way. So, I'll just, an arbitrary example. Let's say that, you know,
your strategy was iron condors. And let's say you said, okay, I want you to sell one standard deviation
iron condors in something that has an IVR of 30. All right. So, there you go. It goes out and it
does that. And then you say, how can you make more money selling spreads above and below the market?
So, must contain both sides. It has to be market neutral. And the machine comes back and says,
well, I'd like to skew it in this way. I'd like to add long units over here. And I'd like to sell
one point two standard deviations instead of one. Okay. Great. Much better. So, we're still on the
same page with respect to the investment ideology, but there's a layer of refined. Okay, so we go ahead
with that. And then we're using the machine learning layer. And, you know, just as an aside,
all true AI has a machine learning layer. If it doesn't have that, it's not really artificial
intelligence. It's just a repeating quantitative process, right? The ability to self evolve is what
makes it artificial intelligence. So, what it's allowed to do in our strategies is modify the
weighting of the criteria that it is using to flag its investment decisions. And it can select
from a larger basket of criteria. So, let's say we give it 50 criteria that it's going to examine
to make an investment management decision in an underlying. But it really only thinks that 21 of those
are informative. And it wakes those 21. It's like these three, man. If I see these, that's a guarantee.
If I see these, it's positive. If I see these, it's still a less positive. But still good,
anything down here, I can't find a correlation with winners or losers, so I'm going to ignore that.
But it constantly reevaluates that basket of criteria. So, over time, as conditions change,
market participants get added, some become more consequential, some become less consequential,
it adjusts within that basket. It can't suddenly say, you know, I'd love to just
short shit all day long. I think that's what I'm going to do today, right? And you're like, whoa, whoa,
whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. Unless there are no guardrails, ours can't do that. So,
it can evolve within that space. In terms of like, are we going to see it get to the point where
it just fundamentally changes the training strategy? No, because it doesn't even know that it
has the ability to do that, right? That's, that's what you get into science fiction at that point.
That's super interesting and well thought out and super well designed. And I'm glad we had an
opportunity to talk about that because I know so many people were fascinated by it and we all know
it's coming. I just hope that there's, there's thought and backtest and humility behind some of
the new AI issues out there and we don't see people get burned in chasing performances. You know
that investors love to do is strategy chase and then all of a sudden there's a problem. But let's
talk about dip. Okay. It's really one of the only pure AI ETF plays in the market today. So why don't
you take, you know, the opportunity to really just talk about the the high level investment strategy
and what is trying to accomplish and what is trying to invest, really trying to get exposure and
sure. So when we were considering which ETF we wanted to launch first, we had a few different choices.
Bleeding edge performance, but you know, more cavitation in the P&L, a broader base of assets
that it could trade, a bigger universe that is or dip, which is what we decided to trade and
or decided to build and what dip does is it looks for artificially oversold conditions
in largely S&P 500 components. So we wanted to keep the universe to something that was
largely seen as safe and stable. Right. So there's no OTCBB, there's no pinks in this,
there's no short, it's long only, it's equity, it's large cap. So you are not going to get
like a plus 80% year out of this by design. Right. It's designed with with safety in mind.
It was our primary sort of goal and it started with the universe and then it started with the
waiting within the universe. So broad diversification, it can't just pile it all into tech and,
you know, you have a accused type of collapse when, you know, semis blow up or technology
sells off because there's lawsuits or anti-trust or whatever in the offing for a bunch of the,
you know, the big nine companies that drive the weight of that ETF. And then obviously the
long only component and then we were looking for something that investors strategy that investors
seem to like, like investors like by the dip. It's an acronym, BTD or if you prefer BTFD,
we did try to get that as a ticker and we're just flat told no. But I guess they never
seems sense of humor. It's something that makes sense on a fundamental level. A stock sell
off, if you're bold, it represents a buying opportunity. Most capable companies over the long term,
or the long term trend upwards. So why buy at the all time high? Why pay the premium? When
it pulls back, there's your buying opportunity by the dip. The problem is that most investors
can't identify what we would consider an authentic dip. And so authentic dip I would say is an
artificially oversold condition. So what the hell does that mean? Okay. So let's, let's use this
analogy that's been working for me recently. You've got a basketball sitting in a swimming pool.
And that represents the stock's price, a fair market value, at any given time, as agreed by the
dominant market participants in the stock. Okay. So it can go up and it can go down if you add
more water to the pool, if you take water out of the pool. Up it goes down it goes, but it's still
sitting on the surface, which means that it is still the fair market value for that stop. Now,
if I take my hand and I put it on the basketball and I shove it under water, I've artificially
depressed the stock, right? That basketball is underwater, but it's only underwater for as long
as I hold my hand there. The moment I take my hand away, it's going to pop back to the surface
of the water. Now, that does work on the other side as well. I can pick it up out of the water.
It's going to be above the surface of the water. So long as I hold it there, I'm not going to hold it
there forever. Eventually my hand's going to get tired. I'm going to drop it back down to the surface
level of stock. Now, wrinkle being as I've pushed it down as I've lifted it up, someone could also
be draining water from the pool or adding the water in the pool. So when I let go, it just stays at
that level. But by and large, that action of pushing the ball underwater leaves a footprint.
And that's what we're looking for. So how does that happen with a stock? So that's, you know,
one of the common ways that it happens is an HFT taking advantage of liquidity pockets and
voids in the inter-day trading of the stock. And that's, that's not like limited to like small
cap low float, like Chipotle's enormous. And it's a liquid as hell in today. I SRG is a monster
company. And it's a liquid inter-day malloy, a liquid inter-day, right? So you have these moments
where spreads blow out. And the HFT will take a couple of feel-or-order pokes at the bid
and see whether or not the market immediately drops down. And then it just unleashes that order
flow, which like, yeah, who can compete with that? You know, it's $10 million or 60 seconds or something
like that just flows in. Stock collapses through, through the bid levels. You know, eats all the
way through that, that side of depth of book until it hits an institutional bison. You know,
and something like FMR is just going to soak up an unlimited number of sellers, right? So like
that's like a freight train hitting a mountain. And the HFT will shut off at that point and they'll
cover. So it's shorted, it's sold down, it's covered. But now it's hit the institutional bison.
And now the stock is going to pop back up. Now the institutional bison is a zone. The
institution is not just going to keep buying it forever. So once it enters into this bracket
in between these two points, they'll be buying when it exceeds the top threshold of the
bracket. It's going to shut off. So you're going to get that little bounce, that that that dip that
pops up. And then maybe it continues, maybe it doesn't, that's not for us to say. So we're looking
for that condition and buying the stock there versus your average investor who maybe sees, you know,
like a 5, 6, 7% pullback. And I was like, oh, hey, it's a dip. But no, that might be the mean
reversion right there. It was over speculated. It was over bought. It's now coming back down to
FMR. It's value. You are not going to get a dip there. There is another reason for that happening.
And so, you know, investors keep coming back to buy the dip because they've had intermittent
success with it, right? They've sometimes they identify authentic dips. They're like sweet.
Thanks for the 11 point pop there. Other times it's like God damn I buy this thing like every time
and it's it's screwed me over and it's not popping back up. Yeah, because it wasn't a dip.
Right. So that's why we took the sort of tried and true investor fan favorite. It said, okay,
AI is really good at identifying authentic dips. If you like the concept of this strategy,
then let us do it for you. And just park whatever you were going to spend on buying the dip
in this ETF and focus on whatever else you want to do with your name. Yeah, I love it. I think it's
extremely interesting. And again, love how it's designed. But I see a mix of index funds as well as
some regular equities in there. Can you talk about that like diversification mix and and
or those are constant kind of holding in there. They're also at a much larger weight at least right now.
But can you talk about kind of how the holdings, I know the equity holdings are going to change,
but what's the reason for the index funds in there? And I did notice at least as of today,
the holdings in those index funds, the weights are a little bit higher. Right. So that actually ties
into a problem that's inherent to some AI systems. Right. So it's easy for science,
science, easy, but it's appealing to build the profit generating mechanism. Right. So you're like,
you're looking for this and here's what you're going to do. When you see this pattern, you're going
to buy it. So what happens when the criteria, the minimum criteria that the AI needs to be successful
